title: food-chef-tom-kerridge-shares-passion-bbqs
story: Barbecues at the ready because chef Tom Kerridge, holder of two Michelin stars, has a trove of summertime cooking treats to share.During the course of his new show, Tom Kerridge Barbecues - on the Food Network, the chef will be showing off some old and new recipes using charcoal, smoke and fire.He talks about his favourite dish from the series and why everyone - including professional chefs - are prone to barbecue disasters from time to time.How did this series come about "I filmed with Food Network last year, a big series for the States, they gave me a call and said listen do you want to do something with barbecues... it was actually a really good, fun thing to do. Im interested in barbecue cookery, its not professional, its much more about social cookery. I love that very much and the idea of making a TV show relatively quickly, getting it turned around, getting it out there, with people that Ive made TV with before, its just like Well, this would be a great way to spend a couple of weeks doing stuff."When did you film "We finished filming Thursdayand the first episode airs on July . So as we were filming, its going into the edit straight away, so its a very quick turnaround and an exciting way of making television."Given that, did you feel pressurised or quite relaxed "Not pressure but it felt quite energised because it was quite a quick turnaround ... Look its not important TV, but its fun TV. Im not making a documentary on Covid- am I  Im cooking beef brisket so its kind of like, its not pressure but its been fun and quick so the energy has been great."If you cook one thing on a barbecue for the rest of your le, what would it be "I think probably short ribs of beef or beef brisket something thats slow-cooked, loads of flavour, they are the sort of things I love cooking. They take a bit more time, but that kind of effort and energy that comes through slow cooking is amazing."Do you have a favourite dish from this series "They are really all good, there are lots of things Ive done on there that have been fantastic. One of the loveliest ones to do was a Spanish kind of chorizo pork burger, so its like a burger butthose lovely warming Spanish flavours it makes you feel very much like its summer time - so its a play on a burger with just a bit more."Have you had any real barbecue disasters "We all have them... barbecue is one of those ways you cook, its sensual and touch and understanding and its not always controlled, its not controlled like a grill or a hob, or whatever  youve got in the kitchen. It is about the coals and the way that theyve been formed. So quite often, things will stick on the barbecue and its learning your way around it and the kind of things you can do to make things not, stick, things sticking on a BBQ haunts everybody, its not just you or anybody  at home - its everyone!"What are your top tips for having a successful barbecue "Planning and preparation is key. Last minute barbecuing is good but you end up just going to stick some sausages on it. Actually to get the best barbecue... planning, structure and marinading or briningor dry rubs, they all take planning, so thats probably the best tip."Have you had a barbecue that sticks in your mind "My th birthday was pretty special,a few years ago, we had round about  people there and we had nine big, egg-style barbecues cooking and we had pretty much every Michelin star chef in the country came and they all bought things to cook on the barbecue, so it was like a massive chef party with loads of people cooking loads of food on barbecues, it was an outstanding day."Has lockdown brought people together, given us a sense of community spirit "Yes, absolutely. It has strengthened community spirit, everyone has taken care of each other, they are all looking out for each other. Particularly within the hospitality industry, have shown themselves as a caring and giving sector that has really wanted to help in any way possible, no matter where you are in the country."Have you found it dficult to keep healthy during lockdown and what have you been doing to keep fit Obviously getting to the gym has been a no-no, so watching what I eat is at the forefront of my mind, and getting out and doing a run, evenI dont enjoy it, forcing myself to move has kept my joints going!Tom Kerridge Barbecues airs from July  at pm on Food Network and will be available on dplay

title: galleries-pandemic-no-festival-galleries-reawakening
story: The year has half-gone and the rains of August are coming, and we are only now a little more free to do the ldquounnecessary and ldquoinessential ndash activities that, for many, turn out to be far more necessary and essential than some might have imagined.Edinburghrsquos galleries are slowing emerging, each in their own way.Up on Calton Hill, the Collective Gallery, resident in Playfairrsquos old Observatory, has sat silent over Edinburgh these past few months, just as their historic telescopes shut their eyes to the skies.Director Kate Gray, weathering the disappointment of a perhaps cancelled Edinburgh International Festival collaboration, is all too aware of the dficult times coming for public galleries. ldquoBut we made it a priority not to cancel any of our commitments to artists, says Gray.ldquoI think wersquore all very aware of our need to get some perspective on our current experiences.The gallery reopened its beautul grounds a few weeks ago. ldquoPeople tell us our site helps them to reflect, so we really wanted to open that out as a resource to the local community.Next, it will reopen the City Dome, which currently contains Julijonas Urbonasrsquos Planet of People, a project that involves scanningvisitors as they enter the space inidually, their images floating up to the domed ceiling.Down the hill, at one of Dundas Streetrsquos commercial galleries, Fine Art Society Director Emily Walsh says, in still quite cheerfully shocked fashion, that the lockdown has been rather good for them. ldquoPeople bought art from our Ron Sandford exhibition catalogue, works no-one had seen in the flesh, at less than pound,. Our June has been as good as any June, although part of that is the John Byrne effect, she says, referring to their current exhibition.ldquoThere are people who have good enough salaries and are not going on holidays, and they are buying art. Since opening to drop-in visitors a few weeks ago, with face masks and hand sanitiser at the door, they have had a steady trickle of visitors.Their main summer ldquoFestival show has been postponed, but the ldquoupstairs show, A History in Small Pictures, will spaciously ring the two floors of the gallery. A brisk walk along Edinburghrsquos now considerably less deserted streets to the west, and the doors of the Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art are still shut, a security guard at the window distanced behind glass asthe Everyman of Lockdown, looking out on the locals who have so much enjoyed the spacious gallery grounds over the past few months.Director Simon Groom tells me their lockdown began in hectic fashion with an urgent tracking down of works on loan. ldquoWe had a Degas in Washington, a Picasso in Canberra, a Van Gogh in Kobe. Exhibitions were postponed or cancelled, ldquobecause a work might be due to be somewhere  six months down the line.The current phase of reopening is an outdoor audio sculpture trail and family activities. Next month, Modern I will reopen, continuing the final instalment of its NOW exhibition, aswe have simply been in stasis, albeit one from which we have emerged to a more distanced, altered reality.That, certainly, chimes with the work of the inspired Katie Paterson, at the heart of this show, whose works, such as the Moonlight Sonata, transmitted to and bounced off the moon, ing in broken chords, resonate with humanity.The Gallery is keen to reflect how le has changed, ldquonot just as a result of the pandemic, but with Black Lives Matter and social inequality.One of the great things about a gallery is that it is a space where you can go and reflect on your place in the world in front of a great procession of artworks from the past, reflecting what people thought at ious times.It gives a sense of community without the commercialism that has eaten into every other public civic space of our lives, and it is one of the last few places where you can do it.Collective Gallery, www.collective-edinburgh.art, Thurs-Sun, am-pm kiosk cafe and toilets availableThe Fine Art Society www.thefineartsociety, Mon-Fri, am-pm Sat am-pmThe Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art www.nationalgalleries.org, Car Park open .am-.pm kiosk cafe and toilets availableThe Edinburgh Art Festival has an up to date list of galleriesrsquo reopening plans at www.edinburghartfestivalCRITICS CHOICETHE Edinburgh Art Festival  might have been cancelled back in March, but all has not been entirely lost.ldquoAbout two months ago, we suddenly realised we could potentially have a small offering that could exist physically in the world, as well as digitally.ldquoWe couldnrsquot have thought of it when we first locked down, says Edinburgh Art Festival Director Sorcha Carey, marking this yearrsquos dates with work from  artists revisiting resonant former Festival commissions, or making new work in response to the pandemic.ldquoIt has been such an extraordinary time to reflect on what matters, inidually and as a society, and we wanted to respond to that, in Edinburgh.The format will involve citywide billboards and online works, but there will also ndash circumstances allowing ndash be a few live performances, and the festival is also supporting the new Black Lives Matter mural trail in Edinburgh, part of a nationwide project by Scottish black, Asian and minority ethnic artists.Of the  commissions, Ruth Ewan has revisited her Sympathetic Magik , to produce a series of posters that are ldquoa call to collective action, and what we can do to protect society.Hanna Tuulikki will re-stage Sing Sign, first performed in a close off the Royal Mile, with a live performance with her collaborator on a digital link-up, the challenge of communicating across a digital screen a pertinent one for us all in the last few months.Also making a reappearance are Peter Liversidgersquos Hello flags , decking parks, iconic buildings and community centres across Edinburgh. ldquoItrsquos an opportunity for us to say hello to each other as we come back out, and to send a wave out to the wider world.Edinburgh Art Festival, locations across Edinburgh and online, www.edinburghartfestival, from July  to Aug DONT MISSOpen by appointment only, the Scottish Gallery is forging ahead with their August exhibition programme, opening their Modern Masters Women at the end of the month, a rigorous overview of the renowned female artists that the long-lived gallery has represented from Joan Eardley to Victoria Crowe, Wilhelmina Barnes-Graham to Emily Sutton. There are some wonderful and hugely erse works here, a testament to the range of human artistic endeavour, of inidual womenrsquos history and stories that resonate all the more given where we find ourselves now.Modern Masters Women, The Scottish Gallery,  Dundas Street, Edinburgh,   , www.scottish-gallery, Jul -Aug , By appointment only: Tues-Fri, am-pm Sat am-pm

title: herald-sunday-letters-readers-talking-week
story: First of all there was no technical reason for there not being a currency union ndash basically it could have been ldquobusiness as usual, as the Governor of the Bank of England at the timeconfidently suggested would actually have been the case, no matter the posturing of Osborne, Balls and Alexander.In particular, though, and in any case, the vote went against independence, so a currency union was moot. Thus the certainty with which Ms Stephenson presents her ldquocase simply has no basis in reality beyond a convenient conjecture.Her musings about membership of the EU, likewise present another unwarranted certainty. It is certainly the case that member countries have their own currencies , but the fact is that the EU has never faced a situation like Scotlandrsquos and thus any certainty about what it might do is unwarranted. In any event, evenMs Stephenson is correct that the EU would refuse an independent Scotland membershipit lacked its own currency, she writes asone is in the EU or not, when the fact is that, routinely the EU enters into association agreements with applicant states prior to full membership. These, while not according voting rights, could give Scotland much of what we want from membership, such as single market access, participation in EU schemes and freedom of movement.Of course,one starts from the proposition that Scotland should continue to be part of the UK, then any forecast of an independent future will be extremely negative. Naturally, we are all entitled to our point of view, but presenting mere conjectures as facts is disingenuous. Ironically Ms Stephenson considers giving  impressions ldquoworse than irresponsible. She might want to look at her own contributions before being critical in this way of others.Alasdair Galloway, Dumbarton.JILL Stephenson is correct, the British nationalist parties vetoed a currency union between Scotland and rUK, though it could only have worked short term in any case.After the break-up of Czechoslovakia, the establishment of new currencies was achieved quickly and pain-free. So Scotland should establish a new currency as quickly as possible, and as Scotland runs a substantial trade surplus we have a good basis from which to start. I prefer the ldquoNorway Option for Scotland, butwe did join the EU, the euro would be fine an optimal currency in a huge trade block on our doorstep.Would an independent Scotland have a per capita share of the substantial UK assets   If not we would then have no debt to repay . Butwe had Clark Crossrsquos trial run , we would spend our revenue for best Scottish bang-for-our-buck, not paying for expenditure outside Scotland ldquoon our behalf. We would not expect to pay any part of, or incur debt on behalf of, HS or renewing Trident, or the rebuilding of Westminster Palace, or any of the myriad of expenditures south of our border, any more than we would pay for spending programmes in, say, France.Of course, under Mr Crossrsquos suggestion, Scotland would have no way to access the many opportunities that a normal self-governing country has, but it would part the veil of dependency and let us see the most excellent vistarsquos that lie beyond. We only have to vote Yes.GR Weir, Ochiltree.I VERY much doubtClark Crosss proposal that Scotland should be given a two year "trial run" at independence would result in the waning of the desire for self-government as he confidently predicts. So far,  countries have gained independence from the UK, none of them has asked to come back and many of them celebrate the day that British colonial powers departed. As for Scotlands sustainability, other nations of similar size in population to Scotland are managing their independence very well, such as Denmark, Ireland, Norway, New Zealand, and Finland and there are plenty of other countries with far smaller populations than Scotland, such as Iceland, who are also thriving with self-respect, self-determination and self-government.Ruth Marr, Stirling.NICOLA Sturgeon often quips that Boris Johnsons a recruiting sergeant for Scottish independence. As a UK governmental committeehighlights "credible" evidence of Russian "influence campaigns" in the run-up to the  Scottish independence referendum, maybe shes confusing the Prime Minister with President Putin Martin Redfern, Melrose.SELFISHNESS OF THE ME SOCIETYI AM sure I was not the only one horried by the mess people left on the streets of Leeds when they celebrated theof their team to the top tier of English football.And just as many must have been appalled at the amount of litter left behind on a beach where many had gone to take advantage of the relaxation of lockdown.What we saw on our TV screens was shameful in relation to those two incidents.Those two sets of people, who were out to enjoy themselves, appear to have had neither common sense nor a conscience about the amount of clean-up which needed doing after their totally insouciant conduct.What could have been easier than to gather up their debris to deposit it in the available litter bins or to bring it home with them to dispose of it in their own refuse disposal bins at home Selfishness and a lack of consideration for others seem to be the characteristics we must expect from those who have no respect for their surroundings which they display in spades with their careless conduct.The me society is all too evident in those two episodes as though some people feel entitled to do what they like and devil take the hindmost.Freedom does not mean that we do not need to follow the rules and observe the proprieties of decency.I hope that those who made the mess felt thoroughly ashamed of what they had done when they saw the evidence of their disrespect scattered on the streets and the beach.Or is that too much to ask of those kinds of people Denis Bruce, Bishopbriggs.ROCK OF SAGESPROFESSOR John Underhill raises important points about the perception of geology in Scotland . Knowledge of geology has never been more important, for understanding and mitigating future climate change and helping Scotland meet the  net-zero emissions target. So it is concerning that the number of applications for geoscience degrees at Scottish universities is in sharp decline.The loss of Higher Geology is undoubtedly a factor, but there are many opportunities within the Curriculum for Excellence and other Highers such as Environmental Science and Geography for pupils to learn how the planet works, and the many dferent ways in which geology and geological processes impact on modern le in Scotland. Organisations such as the Geobus at St Andrews University and Scotlandrsquos Geoparks are doing excellent work in taking geology into the classroom, and placing it in the context of sustainable development. The recent launch of a new charity, the Scottish Geology Trust, recognises the need to support these existing initiatives, and for wider promotion of the importance of geology to Scotland.Angus Miller, Secretary, Scottish Geology Trust, Edinburgh.VIDEO GAGAROBERT McNeils piece on video gaming was embarrassing : there have been holograms with more substance.First, video gaming being for "loners": right, so all those adverts with families playing Nintendo Switch games togetherjust passed him by, as did World of Warcraft, Elder Scrolls Online, Rocket League and the umpteen other cooperation games where you have no chance of advancement or success without teamwork.Next, "all the games had themes of violence and fighting". The biggest-selling this game this year by a country mile is Animal Crossing New Horizons, where the only violence comes from being stung by wasps or a scorpion. Every year theres a new Animal Crossing, it always comes top, andnot that, its the latest in the The Sims series.Mind you, as he later gushed that "bacteria have started eating metal!" ndash er, yes, its called microbial corrosion, and its been known since  as a hazard within sewage systems ndash perhaps we should make allowances for the terminally out of touch Mark Boyle, Johnstone.WHAT THE DICKENS I READ with interest Ron McKayrsquos account of Charles Dickensrsquos visit to the Chinese Galleryand noted that he ended the item with the words ldquoCharles Dickens ... racist bigot.The item is at best facile and at worst mischievous. The picture is by no means as clear cut as Mr McKay attempts to present it. While he is obviously familiar with the titles of some of Dickensrsquos novels, he ought to read Martin Chuzzlewit, in which Dickensrsquos horror of slavery is abundantly clear. He should also read the chapter on slavery in American Notes, which shows Dickensrsquos utter revulsion at the manner in which slave owners treated their slaves.As to the assertion that ldquoDickens didnrsquot have much time for Catholics I would suggest that he read Pictures from Italy, where he will learn that Dickens took issue with aspects of ritual, but not with Catholics as people. He might try Barnaby Rudge, which, as he may know, is an account of the ldquoNo Popery Gordon riots of . It is quite clear throughout that Dickensrsquos sympathies lie wholly with the victims of the disorders. I would venture to suggest that the above assertion is purely mischievous.Dr GM Armitage, Glasgow.

title: need-stop-basking-memories-learn-live-now
story: Clutching those pictures in my hand, carefully holding the edges to avoid getting smudges on the glossy paper, rather than peering at them on a tiny digital screen, felt oddly comforting.Among the images is one of me sitting in the media tribunes, high above the Sir Chris Hoy Velodrome where I was covering the track cycling at the Glasgow  Commonwealth Games ndash exactly six years ago this weekend.It seems like another world: both literally and metaphorically. A golden summer. The Scottish independence referendum was yet to take place. There was no Brexit. People were packed into the stands like sardines and the notion of a global pandemic hadnt even crossed our minds.I look at my face in that moment and wonderI appreciated how simple le was. In truth, I was likely caught between the excitement of being at the Games and stressing about what the top line would be when I filed my report to the sports desk.In the mixed zone, journalists jostled for space, elbows and armpits an occupational hazard as the pack moved like a lumbering, multi-tentacled beast.: Susan Swarbrick: The quagmire of a socially-distanced salutationWe huddled in pens, inches from the faces of athletes still catching their breath. Sweat dripped as they ignored screaming muscles to valiantly puff out a few words. Such close proximity to other humans seems bonkers now.Scotlands Neil Fachie and Craig Maclean won two gold medals in the para-sport tandem. Their team-mates Aileen McGlynn and Louise Haston made it a double silver in the womens event, while Katie Archibald took bronze in the points race.Archibald had to briefly depart the post-race interview to go vomit in a bin ndash a peril when the body is pushed to the limit ndash but ed smiling.I appreciate you indulging me as I remember this. Im sure you have your own memories, whether at the Commonwealth Games, watching the action from home ndash or the many other landmark moments in all our lives that summer.Recent months have seen countless celebrations subdued or put on hold. Since March, Ive been as guilty as the next person of spending far more time looking back than forward.It is the polar opposite to my usual stance of skipping two or three steps ahead. Typically, Ill be daydreaming about a holiday in September, when its still July ndash or talking about Christmas when its only Halloween. Hitting pause during lockdown saw that stop.: Susan Swarbrick: Meet Susan, a pot-bellied, pyjama-wearing vision of my future selfInstead, I sought solace in the past. Yet, as much as Ive enjoyed reminiscing and taking stock, as the reel of le begins turning again, I realise it is time to move forward. But not too fast. Im finally grasping something that has always evaded me. Im slowly learning to live in the now.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald

title: POLITICS WATCH    Guess who is taking on Mrs Thatcher s role as backseat driver
story: Margaret Thatcher reckoned she had been a ldquovery good backseat driver after John Major took her perch. He saw it dferently, calling her interventions ldquointolerable.The Thatcher-Major tussle was something of an exception, with most past leaders taking care not to criticise from the sidelines. Yet the rules, as well as being unwritten, are fluid. Mr Major himself threatened to take Boris Johnson to court for proroguing parliament.Tony Blair has fast become the past premier most likely to pop up with ldquohelpful advice, as he showed on Sky Newsrsquos Ridge on Sunday.With the BBC Sunday programmes now on their summer hols, presenter Sophy Ridge made the most of being the only show in town, breezing straight in on the dayrsquos big story ndash the sudden imposition of a fortnightrsquos quarantine for holidaymakers ing from Spain. Among those caught out by the rule change was Englandrsquos Transport Secretary, Grant Shapps.Jon Ashworth, Shadow Health Secretary, called the Governmentrsquos performance ldquoshambolic."There are holidaymakers in Spain at the moment confused and distressed, there are people about to go on holiday to Spain and the islands like Tenere who are confused, and they dont know whether their employers will allow them to take two weeks quarantine. The Government is just saying, We hope that employers co-operate. I hope I win the lottery on Saturday but that doesnt mean it is going to happen.Dominic Raab, the Foreign Secretary, was a hasty addition to the line-up. On a typical Sunday, Ridge has to make do with grabbing pavement interviews with Ministers when they are on their way to The Andrew Marr Show. This time, Mr Raab was live in the studio, at the requisite two metre social distance.No worker following quarantine guidance should be penalised by employers, he said, including by being put onto sick pay."If someone is following the law in relation to quarantine and self-isolating the way they should, they cant have penalties taken against them."As for his ministerial colleague Mr Shapps being caught on the hop, the Foreign Secretary said it showed the risks for everyone.Mr Raab could not guarantee other countries would follow Spain and be taken off the ldquosafe list."All we can say is weve got this Joint Biosecurity Centre, we monitor the risk in real time, we take decisive swt action and so there is an element of uncertainty this summerpeople go abroad. He will be staying at home over the recess.Tony Blair had the sun-smooched visage of the international globetrotter. Either that or he has been spending a lot of time in one of his back gardens. The latter seems unlikely given how busy he seems to be with the modestly titled Tony Blair Institute for Global Change. Its latest position paper, Learning to Live Alongside Covid-, was ostensibly the reason for his latest appearance.It was a wide-ranging interview covering everything from Russia and China to Scottish independence. You can read what he had to say in full where in the paper, but in summary: Boris Johnson was uselessScottish Labour had been uselessand current Labour leader Keir Starmer was proving usefulIt was fairly predictable stuff for the former Prime Minister, except for the end when Ridge asked why he could not seem to wrench himself away from politics. Isnrsquot it time to take a break, she wondered, go round the golf course or to the shepherdrsquos hut  David Cameron famously opted for the latter, spending a cool pound, on one for his Cotswolds garden.Mr Blair seemed momentarily taken aback. ldquoItrsquos not something I want to do. A lot of people might think thatrsquos exactly what he should do, stop talking about things. But I care about the country, I think we are at a huge moment of change in the world.Addressing the elephant backseat passenger in the room, he went on: ldquoIrsquove tried to do something that previous prime ministers have not done, but in the future I predict that many more will try and do because you leave office when yoursquove still got a lot of years of active working le.ldquoI always say to peopleyou donrsquot want to listen to me itrsquos a free world, donrsquot bother."But Irsquom not going to be playing rounds of golf or sitting twiddling my thumbs. Thatrsquos not going to happen ever.One was reminded of what Mrs Thatcher said after the  election, that she hoped to ldquogo on and on.Keir Starmer will be delighted.

title: bbc-urged-drop-sturgeons-politicised-daily-covid-briefings
story: The party claimed they were "in breach of the Charter of the BBC".The Scottish Toriesalso accused Ms Sturgeon of using the briefings, which attract , viewers across two TV channels, to ldquopromote SNP policy and stir up resentment against the UK Government.Initially held each day, the Scottish Government briefings were recently cut back to three per week, but are expected to increase when schoolsfrom August .Labour complained earlier this month to Donalda MacKinnon, the BBCrsquos director in Scotland, that the First Minister was using the unprecedented airtime to score political points.Scottish Labour deputy Jackie Baillie told Ms MacKinnon the sht in content made ita ldquohugely inappropriate use of public money ten  months from a Hoyrood election.:No coronavirus deaths in Scotland for tenth day in a rowThe Dumbartshire MSP said she felt very strongly that the briefings cannot be allowed to continue in their current format.In recent weeks, economy secretary Fiona Hyslop has also appeared in the briefings to announce funding measures for Scottish businesses and the arts.Ms Sturgeon, iniably at the prompting of the media covering the briefings, has also commented on Boris Johnson, the Union, independence and Russian disinformation.Support for independence has rise to  per cent since the briefings began, and Ms Sturgeonrsquos personal approval ratings have soared.In reply to Labour, Ms MacKinnon last week said the BBC also broadcast UK Government and Welsh First Ministerrsquos daily briefings, and the pandemic remained ldquofar from over.Refusing Ms Bailliersquos demand, she said: ldquoIt is clear that information and advice from the Scottish Government and from the health authorities, necessarily, continues to evolve and, in such circumstances, it it important that we continue to provide public access to the Government briefings.Scottish Labour peer George Foulkes said the response was ldquototally unsatisfactory and has now written back to the BBC demanding a meeting with Ms MacKinnon.In a letter to Luke McCullough, BBC Scotlandrsquos Parliamentary  Corporate Affairs Manager, Lord Foulkes said he, Ms Baillie and Shadow Scottish Secretary Ian Murray had all written to the corporation ldquoexpressing concern about the First Ministerrsquos televised briefings.Writing in his capacity as chair of the Scottish Group of the Parliamentary Labour Party, he said: ldquoThese briefings, which are meant to be for providing information to the public about the pandemic, have become increasingly party political with no opportunity for the right of reply for Opposition parties in Scotland.ldquoIn the past week for example Fiona Hyslop used the briefing to announce grants in the Borders, Dumfries and Galloway and the Northern and Western Isles and the First Minister used the briefing to comment critically on the visit to Scotland by the Prime Minister.ldquoAll of this and more are clearly outwith the purpose of the briefings and in breach of the Charter of the BBC.:Brexit: Petition launched calling for European Union flag to be removed fromoutside Scottish Government buildingsHe said the reply to Ms Baillie last week was one ldquowhich we all find totally unsatisfactory.He concluded: ldquoAccordingly I am writing to seek an urgent meeting with Donalda where the three of us can express our concerns directly.Scottish Tory leader Jackson Carlaw also weighed into the row, saying the briefings had become ldquoincreasingly redundant and were being used by Mr Sturgeon to promote the SNP.He said: ldquoEveryone understood the need for these daily briefings when the outbreak happened, and in the fast-moving months that followed.ldquoBut theyrsquove become increasingly redundant, and are developing into a regular opportunity for Nicola Sturgeon to promote SNP policy and stir up resentment towards the UK Government.ldquoThe BBC needs to stop pretending there is justication for title: libdems-urge-election-watchdog-urged-investigate-new-independence-party
story: The Electoral Commission has been urged to look at the relationship between the Alliance for Independenceumbrella group and the SNP.The AFI, which is led by former SNP MSP Dave Thompson, has said it intends to stand candidates on the eight Holyrood regional lists next May to maximise the number of Yes MSPs elected.Mr Thompson told IndyLive Radio last week thatthe SNP did not win a majority in  ldquoour folk would keep them in power.:Liberal Democrats must support the union to win votesScottish Liberal Democrat leader Willie Rennie claimed ldquofactions within the SNP were trying to game the system and urged the Commission to intervene to block it.The AFI filed its registration papers with the watchdog last week.Referring to the confusion around the  Holyrood election ballot because of how some parties were described, Mr Rennie said: ldquoI am deeply concerned by this proposed attempt to game the voting system and undermine the will of the Scottish people.ldquoThe Electoral Commission should think carefully about whether they should allow such a registration given such recent poor experience in Scotland.ldquoIf this faction from the SNP is allowed to register a political party, with the intentions that they have expressed, then it will result in dferent arms of the SNP appearing under dferent names on the two dferent ballot papers used for the Scottish Parliament elections.:Jo Swinson dons mantle of Defender of the Union as she senses seismic change aheadldquoThat is confusion. The Electoral Commission should look at this seriously to remove any risk of electors being misled again.The AFI dismissed the suggestion that it was an SNP faction, and said that Mr Renniersquos letter smacked of desperation.A spokesperson said: ldquoIf Willie and his Unionists are complaining, we must be doing something right. ldquoReferring to us as a lsquofactionrsquo within the SNP is nonsense.ldquoWe have said from the outset that the Alliance is not aligned to the SNP and is registering as a political party in its own right.ldquoVoters will certainly NOT be confused by our name, which is exactly what it says on the tin ndash the Alliance for Independence.Mr Thompson last week defended the AFIrsquos list strategy as ldquotactical voting by citing how Mr Renniersquos party has for years appealed for anti-SNP tactical votes in the Highlands.

title: city-leaders-beg-help-glasgow-life-faces-38m-black-hole
story: They are seeking emergency talks with Economy Secretary Fiona Hyslop and Finance Secretary Kate Forbes as they admit they will ldquostruggle to deliver current services without central government support.In a blunt begging letter, council leader Susan Aitken and her deputy David McDonald warned that charity Glasgow Le ndash which manages the cityrsquos culture and sports facilities ndash was already facing a shortfall of ldquotens of millions of pounds in commercial income from both venues and events.The Herald understands the financial black hole could be as big as pound million this year ndash posing a signicant and long-term threat to services crucial to the pulling power of the Scottish economy and tourism industry.Ms Aitken and Mr McDonald wrote: ldquoWhile Glasgow Le is committed to doing all we can to continue to deliver as much as possible of our extraordinary cultural output, it is increasingly clear that we will struggle to do so without support from central government.ldquoThe income generated through concert tickets and donations supports Glasgow Le services and all of it has stopped completely. Currently, we predict a shortfall of income running into tens of millions of pounds.The fears of Glasgowrsquos leaders for its artistic and sporting heritage ndash including its Royal Concert Hall or Fruitmarket with their annual half a million visitors ndash come as it becomes increasingly clear the sectors are being devastated by the pandemic.Yesterday, The Herald on Sunday revealed some performing arts venues will be forced to raise ticket prices to cut the risk of Covid amid concerns there is ldquono such thing as a socially distant theatre.At the beginning of this month, Ms Hyslop announced poundm in targeted support for performance arts venues. The UK Government has pledged another poundm to help keep the arts in Scotland afloat.Sector insiders do not believe this money will be enough, as the scale of Glasgow Lersquos financial problems demonstrates.The charity receives about poundm a year from the council to deliver its core services. But it supplements this core funding with fees for everything from swimming pools and gyms and admissions to concerts and events. Its famous museums do not charge visitors but partly make up for this with money from gt shops, cafes and one-off special exhibitions.Glasgow Le is understood to have offset some of its fixed costs by furloughing hundreds of workers involved in this commercial operation. But it has to cover the full wage bills of its core workers.In their letter, Ms Aitken and Mr McDonald, who chairs Glasgow Le, stressed that Glasgow was far more economically dependent on its arts and sports sector than other parts of Scotland.Moreover, city spending on arts and sports delivers a dramatic multiplier effect.The city leaders wrote: ldquoSince , tourism to Glasgow has grown from . million to . million visitors. Spend has grown from pound million to pound million over the same period, helping sustain more than , jobs in the city.ldquoOne of the major draws for tourists to our city is our world-class civic collection and museums service.ldquoMore people visit Glasgowrsquos museums each year than in any other UK city outside of London, with visits reaching more than four million last year. Our museums service is perhaps the most efficient and effective in the country, delivering nice museums on a budget of pound million, with no national funding: compare that to the National Museums of Scotlandrsquos pound.m budget from Government and . million visitors annually."Ms Aitken and Mr McDonald also stressed the value of live music. Glasgow is behind Manchester and London for music tourism but its concerts still generate poundm from visitors to the city every year, they said.Earlier this month Glasgow Le published a schedule for re-opening its venues. Only a third were included in its first phase. Kelvingrove will open its doors in the middle of August the riverside transport museum at the end of the month losing all the income they would have received during the school holidays.This echoes a nationwide pattern. The Association of Scottish Visitor Attractions last month found that nearly half of the nationrsquos museums, galleries, castles and other historic sites may remain closed until .Normally  million people would go through the doors of Glasgow Le venues every year.Mr McDonald told The Herald: ldquoWe have always had a great working relationship with the Scottish Government but now wersquore asking them to step up more, to ensure that the huge contribution Glasgow Le can make to Glasgow and Scotlandrsquos economic and social recovery is fully realised and not held back by the unavoidable financial challenges that have resulted from this global pandemic and lockdown.The city council has been supporting Glasgow Le through the lockdown and is getting some extra money from central governments to cope with extra Covid costs.Insiders stress that local authorities across Scotland have lost substantial revenue while their commercial centres were closed. Glasgowrsquos council-owned City Parking already operates at a loss. But during the lockdown it stopped charging for parking as it tried to help key workers get to their jobs safely. Its very future as an armrsquos- body is now up for debate, insiders say.A Scottish Government spokesperson said it is a ldquohugely challenging and concerning time" for those in the culture and heritage sector."We are doing all we can to support them during the Covid- pandemic," added the spokesperson. ldquoYesterday, we announced a new pound million Resilience and Recovery Fund for independent museums and we continue to have discussions with Museums Galleries Scotland to understand the support needs of the wider sector, including local authority museums and arms- external organisations, such as Glasgow Le, which face future funding challenges.ldquoWe are also working closely with other cultural and heritage funders to ensure a co-ordinated response.

title: eight-simple-rules-help-unionists-start-winning
story: However,we scratch the surface eight has some kudos. It is the number of wealth in Hinduism, the number of gates of heaven in Islam, and is a lucky number in China and Japan, also because of its mythological connection to prosperity.And today I am going to make my case for the power of eight for Scottish unionism, a bedraggled concept which appears in slow decline. There should be no inevitability about this, however, and indeed I would suggest that they may find their own form of prosperity should they follow these eight simple rules. - Understand where you are and why yoursquore thereIn considering the narrative of last weekrsquos visit by Boris Johnson, which was presumably pre-briefed by Downing Street, one would be forgiven for thinking that nobody in the Prime Ministerrsquos operation has seen any of the news which has emanated from Scotland over the last  years. To suddenly be plunged into apparent lsquopanic modersquo is to misunderstand unionismrsquos position. Unionismrsquos deficit has been coming for years. Indeed, far from being a resounding victory, it looks increasingly as though the  referendum simply came early enough on the x-axis for unionism to survive. But unionism is not in the doldrums because of any irresistible pull-factor inherent in Scottish nationalism rather, there is a signicant push-factor involved. Unionism is stuck in an unappealing, perpetual panic, reacting to everything, offering nothing positive. SNP wins an election unionists create the Calman Commission. Yes almost wins the referendum unionists create the Vow and the Smith Commission. It is a humiliating lack of thought, understanding and planning all rolled into one. - Be less emotionalI appreciate I am in the minority as someone who does not feel particularly nationalistic or patriotic, either towards Britain or Scotland, however unionistsrsquo emotional, sometimes rather hysterical, obsession with lsquoour precious unionrsquo is preventing sensible decision making. Too many unionists exude the air of people who are confused and embittered that the general population doesnrsquot share their unrequited love. A more clinical approach, which is much more characteristic of nationalist leaders, would create the space for far more sensible decision making.: Nicola Sturgeon facing questions over her knowledge of Alex Salmond probe - Stop visiting Scotland to lsquosave the unionrsquoThis is a foolish endeavour for a number of reasons, but most obviously it underlines the fact that members of the Cabinet seldom come to Scotland, a part of the UK which they have just as much right to visit as anywhere , including England. Cabinet visits would be far less controversial, more normal indeed,they happened more often. - Stop talking Scotland downUnionists think this is a nationalist trope, but they are wrong: the tone of unionist communications is counterproductive and corrosive. Coronavirus has turbocharged the temptation to revert to this approach, and the notion that an independent Scotland could not have afforded furlough and a range of other measures is now a centrepiece of unionist messaging. It is, of course, nonsense, and while an independent Scotland would inevitably face uncertainty in its initial years, there is no reason to expect that it would not rapidly develop the ideological maturity to create a wealthy country.:Michael Gove not distracted by independence support surge as devolution key to union case - Stop doing the nationalistsrsquo work for themA great deal of unionist action plays directly into the hands of nationalism. Because of the raw emotion , Unionists tend to define victory as denying the SNP something that it wants, without understanding that this plays perfectly into the nationalist narrative. The prime example of this, which is coming at unionists like a herd of buffalo, is the current policy of saying no to a second independence referendum, evenit is secured with a majority of seats, perhaps even votes, on a clear manesto commitment. Unionists may see this as a clever tactic which puts Nicola Sturgeon in a hole, but in the medium- to long-term it is an appalling strategy which pushes soft unionists, dismayed at the denial of democracy, to the other side. - Get Brexit doneBy default, we consider Brexit to push Scotland towards independence, but in fact a swt Brexit with a reasonable deal has a good chance of becoming a positive for unionism. I voted Remain, but despite this I expect the outcome of Brexit to be signicantly less damaging than doomsayers predict, and this, coated in the toxic prospect of a customs border between Scotland and England should an independent Scotland rejoin the EUrsquos Customs Union, may well flip the Brexit issue from the nationalist column to the unionist one. - Do moreFor a group of people who are so ostensibly passionate about keeping Scotland in the union, the UK Government is prone to leaving the field of play empty for the Scottish Government to roam free. Scottish Secretary Alister Jack and his team appear to understand the pitfalls of this better than their predecessors, but much of the damage has been done. Unionists should be bolder about planting their flag on Scottish turf, including in devolved competencies, especially when theyrsquove paid for the flagpole ndash a practice which is considered normal in federal countries. - Finally, itrsquos time for a New UnionUnionists are always chasing the curve reacting, panicking, misstepping. They need to make a calm, clinical analysis of where the people of the nations of the UK want to be in  years, and create a positive, proactive vision of a New Unionism which takes us all there. It is, in my view, highly likely to involve both more muscular unionismas well as an enhancement of devolved powers. They can call this federalism, or any other of the myriad terms people use for it ndash it is what it is. But whatever they call it, unionists should understand that New Unionism has a real chance of appealing to many of the soft centrists whom they have pushed towards nationalism. Without it, they will almost certainly lose the next independence referendum.Andy Maciver is Director of Message Matters

title: agenda-deposit-return-scheme-just-another-diversion
story: ANY child raised in the  s will recall the pleasure of finding an empty lemonade bottle that was worth dwhen redeemed at the local grocers or cafeacute. It was a welcome boost to our pocket money.We cared little about recycling or saving the planet: our only objective was the money.But over the years interest waned and Barrs ended their schemea few years ago when participation rates fell well below  per cent .In the s glass was the first household waste stream targeted for recycling. Its basic constituents are cheap and abundant in the UK, but the benefit for the environment is that making lsquonewrsquo product from glass culletrequires far less energy. So bottle banks prolerated everywhere, often placed at supermarkets to attract families when they came for the weekly shop.When kerbside recycling was introduced two decades ago, performances shot upbut it should be recognised that using aluminium and steel cans for beverages, and the pubs moving away from bottled mixers to aerated cordials meant fewer glass bottles being used in recent years.The Scottish Government has recently spent a lot of time and money promoting a proposed Deposit Return Scheme, designed to recover more plastic containers with an additional benefit of ldquoreducing litter .Every beverage containerwill carry a p deposit. This deposit will only be reclaimable at ldquoauthorised refunders so not every shop selling beverages will also refund deposits. If you live some distance away from an authorised refunder, it might not always be convenient for you to recover the deposits. Some commentators suspect that those who depend on public transport to get around might simply not bother, but therersquos always the safety net that the more responsible householders will continue to use their kerbside recycling services for glass, plastic and aluminium containers. That, however, doesnrsquot address the issue of these customers having paid an extra p container that they might not always be able to redeem.But the devil is in the detail: the deposit is to be p irrespective of capacity: a multipack of  cans will carry a deposit six times that of the equivalent volume available in larger plastic bottles. The plastic industry has estimated that this approach will actually result in more plastic bottles being used, the very opposite of what the scheme is designed to achieve. Germany has already implemented a similar scheme and reports a % increase in plastic bottle consumption.Eventhe proposed scheme does work, there seems to have been little thought given to what will happen to the ed beverage containers . It used to be estimated that the humble milk bottle made between five and seven trips to our homes in its letime. That canrsquot be achieved with plastic bottles, nor do we have the capacity to re-process them.This scheme hasnrsquot been thought through properly. For a start, shouldnrsquot glass containers be excluded  And shouldnrsquot it be volume-specic John Crawford worked in the Scottish waste management industry for several decades

title: album-review-royal-scottish-national-orchestra-rcs-voices-jean-luc-tingaud-cesar-franck
story: Cesar Franck ndash Le Chausseur Maudit Psyche Les EolidesFive years ago the orchestra teamed up with another French conductor, Jean-Luc Tingaud, for a Naxos disc of a symphony and other works by Vincent DrsquoIndy and now the same team has turned its attention to the under-appreciated catalogue of his teacher, Cesar Franck. His influence on a younger generation as a forward-looking composer was immense, but it was allied to a natural dfidence that meant his own success came late in le, despite a precocious start.The three-part symphonic poem, Psyche, at the heart of this album, was completed only three years before the composerrsquos death. It benefits from some fine singing by the students of the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland trained by Tim Dean, and the whole disc is enhanced by the move to the orchestrarsquos new premises on Glasgowrsquos Killermont Street with its superb acoustic. This is passionate music with Wagnerian colours and grandeur but rather less of the pomposity, and the roots of it can be discerned in the companion pieces, Franckrsquos first hit, about ine retribution meted out to an arrogant huntsman, which opens the disc, and the earlier, more impressionistic, Les Eolides.Keith Bruce

Kingdom, works for Scotland, it gives Scots the best of both worlds.ldquoCertainly, my view is that we in the UK Government have a responsibility to work alongside the Scottish Government in order to deliver for Scottish people.The Minister for the Cabinet Office also dismissed the suggestion that his visit to Scotland, along with that of Boris Johnson last week, is in response to a surge in support for independence.He said: ldquoThe Prime Minister being in Scotland, like the Prime Minister being in Wales, Northern Ireland, Cornwall or Yorkshire, is part of the job description.ldquoItrsquos my responsibility in the Cabinet Office to help to coordinate government policy and part of that is making sure that I work alongside the devolved administrations in order to make sure that the UK Government is there to help.:UK Government rejects Kate Forbes calls for more powers following pound.bn of extra Covid fundingWhen asked what justication the UK Government would have to refuse a second independence referendumthe SNP secured a majority at Mayrsquos Holyrood election, Mr Gove said he was only focused on tackling the Covid- pandemic.He said: ldquoItrsquos a very good question but itrsquos also a hypothetical one.ldquoAt the moment, Irsquom concentrating on doing my very best to help Scotlandrsquos economy and Scottish citizens cope with the consequences of the coronavirus pandemic, build back stronger and my horizons at the moment donrsquot extend much beyond making sure that we can do the very best job helping the people of Scotland at the moment.Mr Gove showed his support for the strength of devolution being used as an argument against any future discussion about the union.He said: ldquoI donrsquot want a situation where we have a border and where because of the policies the SNP has outlined, Scotland having a dferent currency and you canrsquot use the pound Sterling in Stirling. I donrsquot think it would be a good idea for people who want to feel both Scottish and British, who want the best of both worlds, to be forced to choose.:Ian Blackford: Boris Johnson must allow independence referendumSNP win Holyrood majorityldquoI think what devolution allows is Scottish solutions to Scottish problems and UK support for every part of the country I think that an approach that respects Scotlands distinct identity and Scotsrsquo own priorities within the framework of the union -I think thatrsquos the best way forward.He added: ldquoI have and I know others in government have always been very conscious about the importance of supporting people across the United Kingdom and making the case that we are stronger together.ldquoDavid Cameron at every stage was clear that it was important to support the United Kingdom and to respect the devolution settlement. When Theresawas Prime Minister, I think everyone recognised that she was strong and instinctive supporter of the United Kingdom and the strengths that it brought and itrsquos certainly the case of Boris Johnson."

title: coronavirus-pet-cat-becomes-first-animal-test-positive-covid-19-uk
story: The infection was confirmed following tests at the Animal and Plant Health Agencylaboratory in Weybridge, Surrey, on July .Downing Street said the pet had shown symptoms of a respiratory infection ldquowith a nasal discharge and some shortness of breath.:Sturgeons husband urged to end SNPs tasteless sale of face masksThe cat and its owners have all made a full recovery.Yvonne Doyle, medical director at Public Health England , said: ldquoThis is the first case of a domestic cat testing positive for Covid- in the UK but should not be a cause for alarm.ldquoThe investigation into this case suggests that the infection was spread from humans to animal, and not the other way round.ldquoAt this time, there is no evidence that pets can transmit the disease to humans.ldquoIn line with the general advice on fighting coronavirus, you should wash your hands regularly, including before and after contact with animals.A private vet initially diagnosed the pet with feline herpes virus, a common cat respiratory infection, but the sample was also tested for Covid- part of a research programme.The case has been reported to the World Organisation for Animal Health in line with international agreements.There have been a small number of confirmed cases in pets in other countries in Europe, North America and Asia.The UKrsquos chief veterinary officer, Christine Middlemiss, said: ldquoTests conducted by the Animal and Plant Health Agency have confirmed that the virus responsible for Covid- has been detected in a pet cat in England.ldquoThis is a very rare event, with infected animals detected to date only showing mild clinical signs and recovering within a few days.ldquoThere is no evidence to suggest that pets directly transmit the virus to humans.ldquoWe will continue to monitor this situation closely and will update our guidance to pet owners should the situation change.A team of scientists at the University of Glasgow Centre for Virus Research are behind the programme to screen hundreds of samples for Covid- infections in the UK cat population.Researchers at the CVR have now completed a full genome sequencing of the virus found in the infected cat.:Scottish bus giant warns  jobs at risk as Covid hits salesProfessor Margaret Hosie, who works on the project, said: ldquoThere have been sporadic reports of cats from Covid- households in Hong Kong, Belgium, France, Germany, Switzerland, Spain and the US that tested positive forand were presumed to be infected from their owners, but this is the first report of an infected cat in the UK.ldquoAll available evidence suggests that the cat was infected from its owners, who had previously tested positive.ldquoThe cat and its owners have since made a full recovery and there was no transmission of the virus to other animals or people in the household.Professor William Weir of the University of Glasgowrsquos School of Veterinary Medicine, said: ldquoThe factors that govern why one species is susceptible to the Covid- virus while others are more resistant are currently unknown, but will likely reveal more about how this virus spreads and causes disease.ldquoAt present, there is no evidence that cats, dogs or other domestic animals play any role in the epidemiology of human infections with .He said cats and dogs with reported infections usually recover and there has been no evidence of transmission occurring between cats or dogs.

title: uk-government-all-ears-nicola-sturgeons-suggestions-improve-uk-internal-market-plans
story: The UK Government has brought forward its proposals for a internal market for all parts of the United Kingdom, following the post-Brexit transition period, which expires at the end of the year.:Michael Gove not distracted by independence support surge as devolution key to union caseThe Scottish Government has warned the plans would be a threat to devolution and Constitution Secretary Mike Russellhas branded a claim by Mr Gove that the Scottish Parliament will be handed  additional powers that are given up by Brussels ldquoa lie and accused the UK Government of attempting one of the ldquomost shocking pieces of dishonesty I have seen from a government.Mr Gove has stressed that ldquo businesses in Scotland can have unfettered access to the rest of the UK, the internal market plans are ldquoin the interests of Scottish workers and Scottish consumers.He said: ldquoOf course, you need to have high standards and we will maintain the highest possible standards on food safety, animal welfare and environmental protection. I also think that the view from lots of businesses is that we do need a collaborative approach, a legislative underpin is a good idea, but I stand ready to talk to the devolved administrations all the time about how we can make it work.:Michael Gove: Border protesters a few bampots who donrsquot speak for ScotlandldquoOne of the points that has been made is that powers are going to Holyrood as a result of our departure from the EU ndash were not taking any powers away, Mr Gove added.ldquoIf itrsquos the case that there are ways that we can make the internal market work even better and that involves in propositions from the devolved administrations maybe shaping the legislation appropriately, then we are all ears.ldquoWe want to make sure that we work with the Scottish Government, the Welsh Government and the Northern Ireland Executive to make the United Kingdom work for everyone.

title: coronavirus-glasgow-scientists-diagnose-cat-covid-uk-first
story: The cat was initially believed to be suffering from a feline herpes virus, a common cat respiratory infection, but a tissue sample sent by the vet to Glasgow University as part of a UK-wide screening project identied coronavirus.The diagnosis was subsequently confirmed on July  after the researchers forwarded the case to the Animal and Plant Health Agencylaboratory in Surrey.The cat, who has made a full recovery, is believed to have caught the virus from its owners.: Thousands volunteer for UK Covid vaccine trialThe UKrsquos chief veterinary officer, Christine Middlemiss, said: ldquoTests conducted by [Apha] have confirmed that the virus responsible for Covid- has been detected in a pet cat in England.ldquoThis is a very rare event, with infected animals detected to date only showing mild clinical signs and recovering within a few days.ldquoThere is no evidence to suggest that pets directly transmit the virus to humans.ldquoWe will continue to monitor this situation closely and will update our guidance to pet owners should the situation change.Glasgow Universityrsquos Centre for Virus Research had appealed for vets across the UK to send in respiratory samples or faecal swabs from any pet cats and dogs they suspected of having the SARS-CoV- infection, based on symptoms and possible exposure through their owners.Professor Margaret Hosie, who works on the project, said: ldquoThere have been sporadic reports of cats from Covid- households in Hong Kong, Belgium, France, Germany, Switzerland, Spain and the US that tested positive for [coronavirus] and were presumed to be infected from their owners, but this is the first report of an infected cat in the UK.ldquoAll available evidence suggests that the cat was infected from its owners, who had previously tested positive.ldquoThe cat and its owners have since made a full recovery and there was no transmission of the virus to other animals or people in the household.In April, the British Veterinary Association said cat owners with coronavirus - or self-isolating in case of infection - should keep their cats indoors.The BVA said it was possible that the virus might be carried between people by touching the animalsrsquo fur.However, Professor William Weir, of Glasgow Universityrsquos School of Veterinary Medicine, said there is currently ldquono evidence that cats, dogs or other domestic animals play any role in the epidemiology of human infections with .: Dentists warn profession is in crisis amid funding an treatment rowIt came as the latest figures for Scotland revealed that there have been no Covid deaths for  days in a row.The number of people testing positive for the virus increased again last week to , compared to , , and  in the previous three weeks. However, the number of tests being processed is also up over the period, from less than , to nearly , last week.The number of people in hospital with the virus fell from  last Monday to  yesterday, with a reduction from three to two for patients in intensive care.Meanwhile, Nicola Sturgeon confirmed that more patients are to be seen at the NHS Louisa Jordan - the Covid field hospital created by converting the SEC events campus in Glasgow.Although it was never needed for Covid admissions,  patients have had orthopaedic and plastic surgery outpatient consultations at the site since the beginning of July as part of an NHS Lanarkshire trial.The First Minister said the service will now be expanded to provide X-rays, CT scanning and ultrasounds, as well as speciality dermatology appointments, to many more patients from several health board areas.Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoAlthough the NHS Louisa Jordan has not been required to treat Covid- patients, it remains a vital asset in our phased approach to resuming NHS services safely where we can.ldquoIt is providing capacity to reduce waiting lists and improve outcomes for patients across Scotland. ldquoShe added that it still ldquostands ready to treat patients with the virus at just a few daysrsquo notice.Jill Young, chief executive of the NHS Louisa Jordan, said: ldquoWe look forward to working with NHS boards across Scotland to help deliver key outpatient and diagnostic services for patients.

title: uk-government-confident-whisky-tariffs-can-removed-post-brexit-us-trade-deal
story: The Minister for the Cabinet Office was speaking during a trip to the Highlands, which involved him meeting traders impacted by the Covid- crisis.Mr Gove was pressed about concerns raised by the Scotch Whisky Association, which is calling for  per cent tarfs introduced by the United States on imports of Single Malt whiskey in October , to be scrapped ndash warning exports of the products to the United States have dropped by  per cent, leading to more than pound million of lost exports.:Michael Gove not distracted by independence support surge as devolution key to union caseBut Mr Gove said that once the UK agrees a new trade deal with the United States, being led by International Trade Secretary Liz Truss,outside of the EU, it would lead to ldquosignicant opportunities for tarfs to be removed.He said: ldquoThe routes of this dispute arise as a result of the way in which America regards the EUrsquos subsidy of the aviation section ndash so itrsquos a European matter, not a Scottish matter.ldquoLizhas a very strong relationship with the American trade representative, Robert Lighthizer. I know that Liz completely understands how important it is to fight for the whisky sector and indeed other areas that are affected by tarfs.:UK Government all ears to Nicola Sturgeons suggestions to improve UK internal market plansldquoLiz has talked to Robert Lighthizer about why it would be a mistake to extend, as has been mooted, tarfs for malt whisky to gin and blended whisky. Shersquos also been very energetic in demonstrating that it would be a strong confidence-building measurewe could see these tarfs removed.He added: ldquoUltimately, one of the challenges, while we are still in the EU, America sees us as part of a trade block that has been responsible for a particular approach towards aviation which inspires a particular approach from them.ldquoThe negotiations that Liz has been leading have been constructive so far and there is a real understanding on the part of people in the US administration that after we leave the EU, there are signicant opportunities for Scotlandrsquos distinctive sectors, including whisky to get treatment thatrsquos fair and right.:Michael Gove: Border protesters a few bampots who donrsquot speak for ScotlandChief executive of the Scotch Whisky Association, Karen Betts, has warned that the tarfs are a ldquoclear and present danger to Scotch whisky.She added: ldquoThe UK Government must now work fast with the US Government to call time on tarfs.ldquoThe UK must use the opportunity of ongoing trade talks with the US to work out what each side needs to do to resolve their dferences and bring an end to tarfs."The damage being inflicted on unrelated sectors such as Scotch, shortbread and cashmere, as well as on American whiskey, is simply unjustiable. We are paying a heavy price for trade disputes that have nothing to do with us.

title: scottish-councils-confident-schools-can-return-full-time-august-11
story: Nicola Sturgeon and her cabinet will decide on Wednesday whether to proceed with plans to fully open schools from August , with the decision announced on Thursday.Giving evidence to Holyroodrsquos education committee, Stephen McCabe, the childrenrsquos spokesman for the council umbrella body Cosla, said local authorities were ready.He said: ldquoOn the basis [of information] I have received from directors of education, they are confident they will be in a position to get schools back into full-time learning during August.He told MSPs councils were also ready to switch to the contingency option of blended learningthe risk from coronavirus was judged too high for full-time classes.However he stressed that school would not simply pick up where pupils left off in March, and that a ldquorecovery curriculum would be needed, with inidual plans put in place for children whose education had suffered most.He said: ldquoItrsquos a huge challenge, ing to full-time education after five months of no education, essentially.Earlier this month, education secretary John Swinney said schools would not need any form of physical distancing among pupils.However last week he told MSPs secondaries would be asked to keep m between pupils ldquowhere possible though controlling flows of students in corridors and new class layouts.But Mr McCabe said: ldquoThe reality is there will be limited opportunities to maintain social distancing in secondary schools.Mr Swinney said safe distancing was a ldquoprecautionary principle that shouldnrsquot be prioritised over full-time education.Mr McCabe, Labour leader of Inverclyde Council, also warned of faced vastly increased costs.Noting East Dunbartonshire alone was looking to recruit  new cleaners to work through the school day, he said: ldquoCleaning on its own is going to be a huge additional cost.ldquoThere will be other costs, around school transport and PPE, the type of logistical costs that will require to be met to safelychildren to school.Although councils are due to receive an additional poundmillion in Government funding, Mr McCabe said talks were taking place with ministers about yet more cash.The guidance being developed for a safeof schools ldquowill come with a heavy price tag that will be ldquosignicantly more than the money already being provided, he warned.Mr Swinney said sample testing for coronavirus would be carried out to track the impact of opening schools on the disease, but it would not be ready on day one.He said: ldquoI have some anxiety about the reopening of schools, because of the degree of change this represents in the arrangements we have within our society.ldquoWe have been in a situation for four months of really very limited contact between iniduals and very limited gatherings, and the openings of schools will be a very signicant next step in the move out of lockdown.Mr McCabe said: ldquoThe stark reality is we know there are going to be incidents of Covid- in our schools, and we are going to have to manage them effectively.Green MSP Ross Greer said: ldquoThe guidance around social distancing for secondary pupils and staff is as clear as mud. Most schools just donrsquot have the space or capacity to do thisevery pupil s full time next month, as they have been instructed to do. Schools have been issued two recommendations which are impossible to deliver at the same time.

title: psychologist-suspended-botched-report
story: Dr Claire Evans-Williams carried out assessments on an inidual facing serious criminal charges despite not being properly qualied to do so.She failed to obtain papers relating to his medical history or the proceedings he was facing in court and relied solely on information provided by him and his family.She went on to advise that the man, known only as Service User A, was at low-risk of re-offending exposing the public ldquoto a serious risk of harm.In a CV submitted as part of her reports on the man in July , Dr Evans-Williams wrongly claimed she was a ldquoconsultant clinical psychologist and said she had held senior positions at NHS Tayside which she had not.Her case was referred to a disciplinary hearing of the Health and Care Professions Tribunal Service .The  suspended Dr Evans-Williams for four months after finding her fitness to practice was impaired.Dr Evans-Williams, , was employed as a clinical psychologist with NHS Tayside but left after  months.She went on to found a private practice in St Andrews, Fe, called the Autism Academy, which provided diagnostic and therapeutic services to autistic adults.The tribunal heard she was contacted by the father of a university student who had been charged with multiple offences of a sexual nature.He asked her to carry out a report on his son to establishhe was on the autistic spectrum in the hope that it would avoid a criminal conviction.Dr Harry Wood, a consultant clinical psychologist who was an expert witness in the case, said Dr Evans-Williams used her own risk assessment tool for the report, which would not be understood by fellow professionals, and called her findings ldquoinappropriate and flawed.In a written decision, the HCPTS  said: ldquoThe registrant acted outside her scope of practice in accepting instructions, carrying out a clinical forensic assessmentof SUA and completion of a clinical forensic assessment reportin respect of Service User A.ldquoThe Panel noted the lack of skill, expertise and experience the registrant had in this area of clinical practice and determined that her conduct demonstrated a signicant and serious falling short of the standards expected of a registrant.ldquoThe Panel noted the evidence that it was unsafe to rely solely on information from SUA and his family alone, in circumstances where the purpose of the report was to avoid criminal proceedings.ldquoIt was hoped by the family that the criminal proceedings would be referred on to a ersionary disposal of the case that would avoid Service User A receiving a conviction.ldquoThe Panel considered it was extremely concerning and serious that the registrant had not utilised an appropriate risk assessment tool.ldquoThe registrant had effectively invented her own tool without reference to anyone. This meant that the assessment of Service User A as at low risk of re-offending, an assessment to be relied in the judicial process, was not properly measured.ldquoThis had the potential to expose both the public and Service User A to risk with serious consequences. The Panel determined this conduct was very serious and amounted to misconduct.Dr Evans-Williams stated on her CV that between August  and March  she had been the lead clinical psychologist within Forfar Community Mental Health Service - a position that did not exist.She also ly stated she had been the personal development coordinator for NHS Taysidersquos psychological services ision.The  also found she was not entitled to call herself a ldquoconsultant clinical psychologist given her limited experience.

title: nailed-lockdown-student-boom-furniture-school
story: Time spent at home without busy schedules and the usual preoccupations has allowed for self-contemplation, new-found passions and an appreciation of what aspects of our lives might need improvement.So itrsquos hardly surprising that many are now making le changes as a result.Data from the Office for National Statisticssuggests that more than a quarter of people across the UK are planning to make big changes to their lives once the pandemic is over ndash including to their careers, relationships and homes.And, at one of the worldrsquos most renowned furniture-making schools, The Chippendale School in Edinburgh, this desire for new skills or a switch in careers has led to a surge in new students.Principal Tom Fraser reports that there has been a lot of interest from middle-aged students looking tomake a change.The professional cabinet-making course was half-full before lockdown but now all spaces are full, with a waiting list.Mr Fraser said: ldquoDespite Brexit and a global pandemic, we have seen more demand than ever for our courses, specically the professional course which is aimed at those seeking to establish themselves as professional furniture makers.ldquoWhile it has taken so much away, the current pandemic has given many people the time to reset and reflect on their lives and plans and this has come through in the many conversations Irsquove had with new students.ldquoA lot of people feel they have slogged for many years in stressful jobs and corporate environments and are not fulfilling their creative potential.ldquoMost applications have come from midle professionals who want to change career completely and do something more creative.ldquoThe next student cohort includes a pilot, an investment banker, oil and gas professionals, project managers, IT specialists and a lawyer.ldquoThe   course, which starts this November, is now full with a waiting list. We have had interest in this yearrsquos course from people from  dferent countries including the UK, USA, Europe, Mexico and Israel, as well as a record number of female enrolments, which is great to see.This year the school roll will include nine women.The not-for-profit school, which was established in , teaches a professional qualication for would-be furniture makers looking to start their own business, as well as ious intermediate and beginners courses for those looking to learn a new skill or take up a hobby.This yearrsquos intake includes students from all walks of le, including afemale private jet pilot who lost her job after  years.Others include a constructionproject manager, oil and gas worker, hospitality manager, an investment banker and IT professionals.One current student, Stewart, aged , was a GP before signing up for the professional courseHe said: ldquoI was a GP for  years before I started studying on the professional course.ldquoI was always interested in woodworking as a hobby, but itrsquos fantastic to now be able to focus my energy on it full-time.ldquoI see woodworking as a means of de-stressing. I feel totally relaxed when Irsquom working on my designs.The new incoming students will start their course in November, while others completing this yearrsquos course willto the workshop in August to finish their studies.The school, which is family run, has welcomed more than  pupils from more than  countries through its doors.While the majority of the coursersquos students are from the UK, others have travelled from the USA, Poland, Russia, Spain, Germany and Israel to learnthe craft.And many former students have now taken up careers in woodwork around the world.

title: four public toilet sites to reopen with more to follow
story: Public toilets at four more sites will reopen on Monday, July .These are at Finstown, Stenness, St Mary’s and Cromarty Square in St Margaret’s Hope, with more to follow over the weeks ahead.Earlier this month, Orkney Islands Council reopened toilets at the Travel Centre and St Magnus Lane in Kirkwall and at the Pier Head and Ferry Road in Stromness.“We are now working on the logistics of opening the toilets at our more remote and rural locations,” said Hayley Green, OIC’s Head of IT and Facilities.“The reason we cannot reopen all toilets at once is to ensure we comply with Government guidelines, which include having to introduce more frequent cleaning to reduce the risk of COVID- transmission to the public and to our staff.“We will publicise all re-openings as soon as we can confirm the dates.”If you find any problems with any of the opened toilets, please contact OIC Customer Services on , giving details of the issue and the location of the toilet.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
